node.title: Kathryn put high school on hold for chemo. Years later, she's graduating from medicine with a Rhodes scholarship
node.alt: Kathryn Woodward with a shaved head.
node.description: A young woman is about to graduate with a medical degree from Griffith University after battling lymphoma at the young age of 15. She wants her story to inspire change.
node.content:
["Having to go to the hospital for chemotherapy filled Kathryn Woodward with so much dread, she used to throw up before she even got there.", "Ms Woodward was 15 and living on the Gold Coast when diagnosed with Hodgkin's Lymphoma, a type of blood cancer.", "Although she had decided on medicine as a career before her diagnosis, when her initial cancer treatments failed to work, even finishing school was not guaranteed.", "She had to put high school on hold while she endured chemotherapy, radiation\u00a0and a bone marrow transplant using stem cells donated by her older brother, Jonathan.", "", "
Kathryn at the beach at a time she was undergoing\u00a0treatment.\u00a0(Supplied)
", "Almost a decade later, the young woman who once found entering a hospital as \"the absolute worst\" will soon be graduating in medicine at Griffith University with distinction.", "
'A difficult time'
", "", "
Ms Woodard said having cancer was a traumatic thing for a young person to go through.(Supplied)
", "The 24-year-old was also recently granted a Rhodes scholarship to further her studies at Oxford into how to improve health systems.", "\"I remember being at school thinking: Do I ever want to walk into a hospital again?\"\u00a0Ms Woodward said.", "\"It was understandably fairly traumatic for a young person to go through a cancer diagnosis and all that that entails. It was a fairly psychologically difficult time.\"", "But early next year, she'll walk into the Toowoomba Hospital as an intern and head to the University of Oxford in September to take up her two-year Rhodes scholarship, one of only nine granted in Australia this year.", "These days, Ms Woodward finds walking into a hospital with a stethoscope around her neck \"a satisfying experience\" and she has dreams of specialising in public health, working to drive improvements in how health care is delivered.", "", "
Kathryn attending\u00a0a wedding as a bridesmaid soon after treatment finished.(Supplied)
", "During her time at university, she became a patient advocate, joining the Queensland Youth Cancer Services advisory group.", "After receiving help from CanTeen Australia during her own cancer journey, she took up leadership positions with the young person's support organisation, joining its board of directors three years ago and is the current deputy chair.", "\"It took me a little while to come to terms with my own experience and then be in a place where I felt like I could give back and contribute in a way that would mean the next young person with cancer may have a slightly better experience than I did,\" Ms Woodward said.", "
Changing\u00a0healthcare systems\u00a0
", "", "
Kathryn with her brothers Jonathan (left) and\u00a0Ryan (right) when she graduated with a Bachelor of Medical Science.(Supplied)
", "When she first entered medical school after completing a Bachelor of Medical Sciences at Griffith University, her vision for her future was working one-on-one with patients, \"like the really dedicated and empathetic doctors that treated me\".", "But that has transformed to wanting to help change health systems so they better adapt to patients and the communities they live in.", "For example, earlier this year she was involved in a project providing flu vaccinations to Indigenous teenagers at their local sports hall in Toowoomba, demonstrating the critical role individualised healthcare approaches can play.", "\"It will allow me to build the academic foundation for my future in public health as part of a community of students and academics who are global leaders in their fields.\"", "She also hopes to use her story to show other young people facing adversity they can use their experiences to make a difference in other people's lives."]
